sentences.sentence: ASIC has its limitationsin regulating breachesClime Capital Limited and myself (as chairman) have been the lead applicant of two class actions against listed ASX companies.

The basis of those claims is on the public record and both were taken by Clime under the direction of our board to comply with our fiduciary duties.The opinion piece by Professor Kevin Davis ("Shareholder class actions a blunt weapon that make no sense", June 17) draws its conclusion from a significant misunderstanding of the capability and capacity of ASIC to undertake the dual role of the regulation of capital markets and the enforcement of breaches.ASIC has often publicly stated that it will assess its desire and willingness to undertake enforcement pursuant to a "public interest test".

Thus, many breaches are not investigated and enforcement and prosecution not undertaken, while others pass the "public interest test" without clarity as to how this test is applied.The "public interest test" appears to seek to solve the problem of a limited budget and resources at ASIC.

This may be pragmatic on one reading, however it risks poor outcomes and introduces subjectivity where, on an objective view, breaches of the law have taken place.Professor Davis needs to understand this before he suggests that the current structure of ASIC can solve the problems with the continuous disclosure regimes of the ASX market.A collaborative understanding and relationship between market practitioners and the regulator would go some way in solving the issues the professor outlined.John AbernethyClime CapitalSydney, NSWBusiness leaders bluntour competitive edgeThe article "Tax, timid managers hurt our ability to compete" (June 17) mentions that Australian management practices rate poorly, at 48th out of 63 in the annual IMD World Competitiveness Yearbook, but its major emphasis is on our tax regime.LSE/McKinsey have found that lifting our management practice score from its current 3 out 5 to 4 (above the US, Japan and Germany) would be the equivalent of a 56 per cent increase in the labour force or a 44 per cent increase in invested capital!Business ignores this opportunity, unwilling to disrupt the current paradigm (and wilfully resisting change), preferring to push the government for tax relief.

We deserve better from our business leaders.Philip RadburnGladesville, NSWBig banks' pre-Haynehabits seem to lingerFollowing the Hayne royal commission, it would be reasonable to expect that the big four banks are attempting to refresh their cultural woes.

Yet there is evidence to the contrary.The Australian Banking Association ("Choice wrong on $6.3b 'stolen' in card rates: banks", June 11), slapping down Choice chief executive Alan Kirkland, dismissing his observations as a publicity stunt, is reminiscent of pre-Hayne industry condescension.
The ABA's gesticulations about unsecured credit distract from open communication about the big four's credit card tactics.

Shareholders, too, can but wonder what the big four's cards businesses are doing to be competitive in light of what James Dougherty of Lennox Capital, explains as "... a generational change of people that don't use credit cards" ("Why the market has it wrong on Appen", June 15).

To paraphrase author Upton Sinclair, perhaps cosseted business leaders find it too hard to see something, when their salary depends on their not seeing it.Marcus ConnorCamberwell, VicMost Australian uninames fail 'woke' testThere has been concern about the "woke" appropriateness of the name of so many of our universities.
Of the 42 in Australia, precious few would pass muster.
Some that would have to be renamed are obvious - Flinders, Charles Sturt, Macquarie, Murdoch, La Trobe, Bond and Monash, for example.
But other less obvious universities are also in the mix - Curtin (White Australia policy, conscription WWII), Edith Cowan (pro-conscription activist WW1 and conservative MP).

Even some of the universities with geographically based names will have to reflect deeply on their "woke" appropriateness - Tasmania, Victoria, Queensland, Adelaide etc.It is probably best if we just give them all numbers.Bill AndersonSurrey Hills, VicLeyonhjelm's COVIDviews are best ignoredDavid Leyonhjelm criticising the response to the COVID crisis as an overreaction ("Medicos' massive lockdown mistake", June 12) is so breathtakingly absurd as to be best viewed as a joke.Who could possibly know what the outcome would have been if we had called on the public only to keep their distance and wash their hands?

Yet getting it wrong could have resulted in the loss of thousands of lives.Leyonhjelm's subsequent urging that politicians should have consulted with veterinarians to establish best practice for the treatment of the virus elevated his contribution to the stratosphere of pure silliness.

Is there not some minimum standard of lucidity that the contributions of this former politician must meet?Patrick HockeyClunes, VicEY partners piggybackoff employees' pay cutsEY has demonstrated, once again, that there is no depth the big four firms won't plumb ("Cuts to staff pay help EY maintain partner profit", June 17).While market conditions are difficult, using this to stabilise partner drawings at the expense of their lowest- paid employees is disgusting conduct.
Partners sign up to, and should, be exposed to the full financial risk of market conditions, not those employed on a fixed salary.
I would hope that EY will review its remuneration model and give all employees access to the sizeable variable rewards that partners enjoy.
EY's tagline of "Building a better working world" appears to apply only to the partnership.Michael KinderSherwood, Qld

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
